I'm thankful that my department chair and my students were ok with my pivoting classes to online. My dad never had internet installed in his house (hasn't touched a computer since 1989), so I've been, uh, borrowing wi-fi wherever I can.

One thing I like to do when teaching via zoom is to stop midsentence and hold very still so that the screen seems to be frozen. I start again in the middle of a new sentence.

This really confuses students when something is obviously moving behind me.

The way we use "give" in exams, assignments, etc. has always seemed off to me: give a proof..., give an example..., and so on

More honest, albeit verbose, would be:

I'll trade you a passing grade on this problem in exchange for an example of .... Do we have a deal?

Non-set theorists: Do you know Hartogs' theorem that cardinal trichotomy (given two sets X and Y, one injects into the other) is equivalent to the axiom of choice? If you know the theorem, do you know the proof off-hand?
Confusingly, there's also a result in complex analysis known as Hartogs' theorem.
He was interested in many things, I guess. Very sad ending to his life.
Know theorem (not proof), didn't know its name.

today's mathematical existential crisis: what the fuck is a determinant???

I mean I know what it IS but what IS it. what is happening in there. why does it feel so... loopy

+1 on this. The actual motivation for this question is a paper called “Traces in Complex Hyperbolic Geometry” by John Parker. It has links with the characters and I kinda get it… but… I kinda also don’t. Plus, links to geometry. Horror!

https://dro.dur.ac.uk/11853/1/11853.pdf…

Tbh, I've not thought much about interpreting the trace beyond "derivative of determinant" or "decomposing into projections onto 1-dim subspaces." The latter perspective is suggested by the coordinate-free definition coming from the canonical isomorphism between End(V) and V⊗V*.

Paul Benacerraf insists that numbers cannot be sets, for there are multiple ways numbers could be sets but no principled way to choose amongst those options. Sadly for Paul, we can use a global choice function to canonically make that choice, solving his identification problem.

This resonates because as someone who spends a good chunk of his research time thinking about off-the-beaten path algebraic gadgets, I have been accused many times by people doing fashionable stuff of doing broadly uninteresting work.

I prefer to think of my taste as esoteric.

A different method is as follows: Fix an element a and define two new binary operations as follows: x*y=(xa)y and xoy=x(ay). Form their Cayley tables and compare them. If, for all a, the two tables coincide, then the original operation is associative.

[2/21]

Let's start with the mathematics. Given a finite set with a binary operation, suppose you want to determine if the operation is associative. The naive method is just to examine all triples (a,b,c) of elements of the set to check if (ab)c=a(bc).

Tomorrow we'll be doing a little recap in Calc 2 using one of my favorite activities. I think I've shared this before here, but students will fill out this chart in groups, using examples for combinations that are possible and explanations for combinations that aren't.
Yah that's huge for them. They've done since preliminary work with them, but this is hopefully where they'll make some big ideas come together.
I was taught that an infinite series *is* the sequence of partial sums, denoted with the summation symbol. It was eye opening years later when I found out that not everyone learned it that way.
It was probably a couple of years ago now. It's a fun way of getting some discussion going with students!
It also seems like a good way to get them to think about what an infinite series actually is. Is it just a symbolic thing? Is it any different from the sequence of partial sums? Etc.
Interesting! I don't think I saw this the first time you tweeted it.

I always discuss this explicitly the first time it occurs in class: "We could start with 'Let x... Then x= ...' but we will be less likely to make an error if we assume up front that our arbitrary element of (blahblahblah) has the form we need."

This is based on 30+ years of teaching this and having students consistently unable to bridge the gap between "x" and the particular object they really need. 

It's also based on just now grading a final exam.

If I am a referee for one of your papers, it is actually to your advantage if I procrastinate. The longer I leave the report unwritten, the more guilty I feel. The more guilty I feel, the more likely I am to recommend accepting the paper.
Care to guess why I tweeted this last night?
I mean, you as an author have to solicit an answer from the referee at least once  through the editor of course
Ah yes, quite so!
But for this to work properly you have to sollecitate energetically at least once
